00040 #ifndef _scenemanager_h
00041 #define _scenemanager_h
00042 
00043 #include "crossplatformexport.h"
00044 #include "datatypes.h"
00045 #include "managerbase.h"
00046 #include "quaternion.h"
00047 #include "vector3.h"
00048 
00049 namespace Ogre
00050 {
00051     class SceneManager;
00052 }
00053 
00054 namespace phys
00055 {
00056     class World;
00057     class Light;
00058     class Plane;
00059     class ParticleEffect;
00060     class Node;
00061     ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00062     /// @class SceneManager
00063     /// @headerfile scenemanager.h
00064     /// @brief This class contains utilities and functions to allow the manipulation of the Graphical
00065     /// scene, rather then the physics inside, or the object inside.
00066     /// @details This class contains functions that allow the manipulation of lighting, skyboxes, internal
00067     /// scenemanager types, and more.
00068     ///////////////////////////////////////
00069     class PHYS_LIB SceneManager : public ManagerBase
00070     {
00071         public:
00072             enum SceneManagerType
00073             {
00074                 Generic,
00075                 Exterior,
00076                 ExteriorRealFar,
00077                 Interior
00078             };
00079         protected:
00080             /// @brief Pointer for the Ogre Scenemanager, where this manager gets it's functionality.
00081             Ogre::SceneManager* OgreManager;
00082             /// @brief Vector storing all the nodes in use by this class.
00083             std::vector< Node* > Nodes;
00084             /// @brief Vector storing all the lights in use by this class.
00085             std::vector< Light* > Lights;
00086             /// @brief Vector storing all the particle effects in use by this class.
00087             std::vector< ParticleEffect* > Particles;
00088         public:
00089             /// @brief Class Constructor.
00090             /// @details Standard class initialization constructor.
00091             /// @param Name Name for the created Scene Manager.
00092             /// @param ManagerType Type of Scene Manager to be created.
00093             /// @param world Pointer to the world which will work with this Manager.
00094             SceneManager(const String& Name, SceneManager::SceneManagerType ManagerType);
00095             /// @brief Class Destructor.
00096             /// @details The class destructor.
00097             ~SceneManager();
00098             /// @brief Inherited from ManagerBase.
00099             void Initialize();
00100             /// @brief Inherited from ManagerBase.
00101             void DoMainLoopItems();
00102             /// @brief Creates a skyplane for use in making a sky.
00103             /// @details Only one skyplane can exist in a scene.  Making a new one will remove the old one.  Skyplanes are
00104             /// flat planes that face in one direction.  They are ideal for levels with surrounding mountains or anything
00105             /// where the horizon is not visable.
00106             /// @param SkyPlane The plane that will become the sky.
00107             /// @param Material The name of the material to be applied to the skyplane.  Note: This is not referring to the
00108             /// filename, but the specific material script within the file.
00109             /// @param Group The resource group where the material can be found.
00110             /// @param Scale The scaling to be applied to the skyplane.  This may need to be tweaked based on how high you
00111             /// set the plane off the ground.
00112             /// @param Tiling The number of times to tile the texture or textures listed in the material script across the skyplane.
00113             /// @param DrawFirst Whether or not the skyplane should be the first thing rendered in the scene.  Usually you will
00114             /// want this to be true as it'll ensure all other objects are rendered on top of it.
00115             /// @param Bow This will add curvature to the skyplane if set above zero.  Note: Use small numbers.  A bow of 1.5
00116             /// should be noticable.
00117             /// @param XSegments The number of segments, or boxes, the skyplane consists of on the planes X axis.  This is usful
00118             /// when giving the skyplane a bow.  By default the skyplane is just one massive box.
00119             /// @param YSegments The number of segments, or boxes, the skyplane consists of on the planes Y axis.  This is usful
00120             /// when giving the skyplane a bow.  By default the skyplane is just one massive box.
00121             void CreateSkyPlane(Plane& SkyPlane, String& Material, String& Group, Real Scale=1000.0, Real Tiling=10.0,
00122                                 bool DrawFirst=true, Real Bow=0, int XSegments=1, int YSegments=1);
00123             /// @brief Disables the currently active skyplane.
00124             /// @details Using this function effectively deletes the skyplane, so you will have to provide a new set of parameters
00125             /// if you wish to re-create the skyplane.
00126             void DisableSkyPlane();
00127             /// @brief Creates a skybox for use in making a sky.
00128             /// @details Like skyplanes, only one can exist per scene.  Unlike skyplanes, skyboxes will be applied individually to
00129             /// each camera in the scene.  The skybox will move with the camera, so as a result the camera will never be able to
00130             /// "touch" the sky.  Skyboxes are more performance intensive then skyplanes.
00131             /// @param Material The name of the material to be applied to the skybox.  Note: This is not referring to the
00132             /// filename, but the specific material script within the file.
00133             /// @param Group The resource group where the material can be found.
00134             /// @param Distance The distance from the camera where the skybox is found.  This is in world units.
00135             /// @param DrawFirst Whether or not the skybox should be the first thing rendered in the scene.  Usually you will
00136             /// want this to be true as it'll ensure all other objects are rendered on top of it.
00137             /// @param Orientation Optional quaternion to rotate the orientation of the skybox.
00138             void CreateSkyBox(String& Material, String& Group, Real Distance, bool DrawFirst=true, Quaternion Orientation=Quaternion());
00139             /// @brief Disables the currently active skybox.
00140             /// @details Using this function effectively deletes the skybox, so you will have to provide a new set of parameters
00141             /// if you wish to re-create the skybox.
00142             void DisableSkyBox();
00143             /// @brief Creates a skydome for use in making a sky.
00144             /// @details Like the other two types of sky's, their can be only one skydome per scene.  Skydomes much like skyboxes, except
00145             /// they have 5 sides(the bottom side is missing), and they bow each of the sides to make the dome.  In all other respects they
00146             /// are the same.
00147             /// @param Material The name of the material to be applied to the skydome.  Note: This is not referring to the
00148             /// filename, but the specific material script within the file.
00149             /// @param Group The resource group where the material can be found.
00150             /// @param Distance The distance from the camera where the skydome is found.  This is in world units.
00151             /// @param Curvature Curvature of the dome.  Usually you want this value to be between 2 and 65.
00152             /// @param Tiling The number of times to tile the texture or textures listed in the material script across the skydome.
00153             /// @param DrawFirst Whether or not the skybox should be the first thing rendered in the scene.  Usually you will
00154             /// want this to be true as it'll ensure all other objects are rendered on top of it.
00155             /// @param Orientation Optional quaternion to rotate the orientation of the skydome.
00156             /// @param XSegments The number of segments, or boxes, the skydome consists of on the dome's X axis.
00157             /// @param YSegments The number of segments, or boxes, the skydome consists of on the dome's Y axis.
00158             void CreateSkyDome(String& Material, String& Group, Real Distance, Real Curvature=10.0, Real Tiling=8.0, bool DrawFirst=true,
00159                                Quaternion Orientation=Quaternion(), int XSegments=16, int YSegments=16);
00160             /// @brief Disables the currently active skydome.
00161             /// @details Using this function effectively deletes the skydome, so you will have to provide a new set of parameters
00162             /// if you wish to re-create the skydome.
00163             void DisableSkyDome();
00164             /// @brief Sets the ambient light for the scene.
00165             /// @details Not all scene's will need ambient light.  Ambient light is light that hits all objects from
00166             /// all directions.
00167             /// @param Red The value representing the amount of red color in the ambient light.
00168             /// @param Green The value representing the amount of green color in the ambient light.
00169             /// @param Blue The value representing the amount of blue color in the ambient light.
00170             /// @param Alpha The value representing the transparency of the color in the ambient light.
00171             void SetAmbientLight(Real Red=1.0, Real Green=1.0, Real Blue=1.0, Real Alpha=1.0);
00172             /// @brief Creates a dynamic light.
00173             /// @param Name The name to be given to this light.
00174             /// @return Returns a pointer to the light class which was created by this function.
00175             Light* CreateLight(const String& Name);
00176             /// @brief Gets an already created light by name.
00177             /// @return Returns a pointer to the light of the specified name.
00178             Light* GetLight(const String& Name);
00179             /// @brief Gets an already created light by index.
00180             /// @return Returns a pointer to the light at the specified index.
00181             Light* GetLight(Whole Index);
00182             /// @brief Gets the number of lights created and stored in this manager.
00183             /// @return Returns the number of lights this manager is storing.
00184             Whole GetNumLights();
00185             /// @brief Deletes a light and removes all trace of it from the manager.
00186             /// @param light The light to be destroyed.
00187             void DestroyLight(Light* light);
00188             /// @brief Creates a particle effect.
00189             /// @details Particle effects are useful when trying to create visual effects for rain, smoke, explosions, fireworks, etc..
00190             /// @param Name The name to be given to this particle effect.
00191             /// @param Template The particle script (from a .particle file) to base this particle effect on.
00192             /// @return Returns a pointer to the particle effect class which was created by this function.
00193             ParticleEffect* CreateParticleEffect(const String& Name, const String& Template);
00194             /// @brief Gets an already created particle effect by name.
00195             /// @return Returns a pointer to the particle effect of the specified name.
00196             ParticleEffect* GetParticleEffect(const String& Name);
00197             /// @brief Gets an already created particle effect by index.
00198             /// @return Returns a pointer to the particle effect at the specified index.
00199             ParticleEffect* GetParticleEffect(Whole Index);
00200             /// @brief Gets the number of particle effects created and stored in this manager.
00201             /// @return Returns the number of particle effects this manager is storing.
00202             Whole GetNumParticleEffects();
00203             /// @brief Deletes a particle effect and removes all trace of it from the manager.
00204             /// @param particleeffect The particle effect to be destroyed.
00205             void DestroyParticleEffect(ParticleEffect* particleeffect);
00206             /// @brief Creates a node that will orbit around a point.
00207             /// @details This will create 2 nodes in the scene, the first being the point in the world you want to orbit
00208             /// the second node around.  The second being the node that does the orbiting.  You can then attach a light,
00209             /// particle effect, or ribbon trail to the orbiting node .
00210             /// @param Target The location of the first node which you will be orbiting around.
00211             /// @param RelativeLoc The location of the node that will be in orbit relative to the first node.  Assume the
00212             /// first node is at Origin (0,0,0).
00213             Node* CreateOrbitingNode(const String& Name, Vector3 Target, Vector3 RelativeLoc, bool AutoTrack);
00214             /// @brief Creates a stationary node that will look at a location.
00215             /// @details This will create a node that doesn't move, and will look at one location that you specify.  This
00216             /// node can then have lights, particle effects, or ribbon trails attached to it.
00217             /// @param LookAt The location you want the node to look at.  Automatically handles orientation.
00218             /// @param Location The location of the node itself.
00219             Node* CreateStandNode(const String& Name, Vector3 LookAt, Vector3 Location);
00220             /// @brief Gets an already created node by name.
00221             /// @return Returns a pointer to the node of the specified name.
00222             Node* GetNode(const String& Name);
00223             /// @brief Gets an already created node by index.
00224             /// @return Returns a pointer to the node at the specified index.
00225             Node* GetNode(Whole Index);
00226             /// @brief Gets the number of nodes created and stored in this manager.
00227             /// @return Returns the number of nodes this manager is storing.
00228             Whole GetNumNodes();
00229             /// @brief Gets the number of stand type nodes created and stored in this manager.
00230             /// @return Returns the number of stand type nodes this manager is storing.
00231             Whole GetNumStandNodes();
00232             /// @brief Gets the number of orbit type nodes created and stored in this manager.
00233             /// @return Returns the number of orbit type nodes this manager is storing.
00234             Whole GetNumOrbitNodes();
00235             /// @brief Deletes a node and removes all trace of it from the manager.
00236             /// @param node The node to be destroyed.
00237             void DestroyNode(Node* node);
00238             /// @brief Gets the name of this manager.
00239             /// @return Returns the name of this manager.
00240             ConstString& GetName();
00241             /// @brief Gets the type of manager that this manager is.
00242             /// @return Returns an enum value representing the type of manager that this manager is.
00243             ManagerBase::ManagerTypeName GetType() const;
00244             /// @brief Gets the internal Ogre Scene Manager pointer.
00245             /// @return Returns a pointer to the ogre Scene Manager.
00246             Ogre::SceneManager* GetGraphicsWorldPointer();
00247     };//scenemanager
00248 }//phys
00249 
00250 #endif
